column13: Add check for any attempt to append data after the cdata element was closed.
column20:
[Resubmitting on other repo]
I noticed that any whitespace after a CDATA item in the metadata of a GIFTI file causes a segfault. Adding an extra check here allows the library to parse what appear to be legal GIFTI files. See for example the file RY_TAL_RH_RECOSM.surf.gii in the archive:
http://www.nitrc.org/frs/download.php/377/SurfaceInBrainVoyagerAndGIfTI.zip
Before applying this fix, gifti_tool will crash reading this file. Afterwards, it complains about the version number, but otherwise parses the file correctly.
I hope this is useful.

column21:
The Makefile contains a line:
CCOLD  = /usr/bin/gcc -V 34 -O2 -m64 -fPIC -DREAD_WRITE_64 -DLINUX2 $(CEXTRA)

and using grep -r CCOLD *, the most relevant lines seem
Makefile.INCLUDE:       $(CCOLD) -D__COMPILE_UNUSED_FUNCTIONS__ -c nifti/nifticdf/nifticdf.c $(INFLAGS)

and
afni_history_rickr.c:   "update CCOLD to compile with gcc verion 3.4",
afni_history_rickr.c:   "add CCOLD to all for compiling nifticdf.o on linux_xorg7_64 using gcc v3",

@afni-rickr, do you think a more recent gcc can be used for nifticdf.c?

column21:
I do not expect that gcc bug to affect modern systems.
Use of 3.4 was because of an optimization bug in versions 4.1-4.3.0 (or so), when dealing with that file.  It was fixed at some point, but I do not know exactly when.  Taking a look, maybe even 4.3.2 is okay (testing that now).  Yup, even the 4.3.2 compiler on a Fedora 10 system is modern enough not to need that -V option.
Note that the far more current Makefile that I personally work with is other_builds/Makefile.linux_fedora_19_64, which uses identical CC variables (e.g. $CCOLD==$CC).  That Makefile is probably a cleaner starting point than an openmp version.

column21:
libtracktools is locally compiled (under ptaylor).  If you are compiling via "make -f xxxMakefile.xxx ...", it will not work.  The ptaylor directory (and maybe some other one) requires a parent "Makefile", meaning you would need to do something like:
cp other_builds/Makefile.linux_fedora_19_64 Makefile
make itall
(so that src/Makefile exists)

column21:
This is something that I would want to verify locally.
One thing to note about those top-level Makefiles: they were not written for general use, but for creating distribution binaries on very specific machines.  It is on those machines that I would like to test.
On that note, we would only change active Makefiles or the ones under other_builds, not alter historic Makefiles.  Maybe I should move the old ones to a sub-directory, we'll see.
At any rate, I will start looking into this change, but will do so slowly.
Perhaps the best places to start are for the openmp and ubuntu Makefiles, since those are used on systems that seem to not come with libXp anymore.
Does that seem reasonable?

column21:
whatever floats your boat @afni-rickr .  as long as there is activity/progress - I would be happy ;-)  I would also be interested to discover which systems still alive need that libXp.  And FWIW, you (if you use bash or zsh) might benefit from this helper I use:  http://git.onerussian.com/?p=etc/bash.git;a=blob;f=.bash/bashrc/30_aliases_sh;hb=HEAD#l857
so I would do ghpr co-head https://github.com/afni/afni/pull/30 to get a pr-30 branch which would be with the proposed PR state.  or use "co" instead to get a state with merged master.  This way I can review/check PRs quickly on my system

column13: RF: remove -lXp (I do not think it is used, obsolete, removed from debian) from Makefile*ubuntu*
column20: I think we never linked against in our NeuroDebian builds...  do you actually need it?  sending to travis to check ;)
column21:
Yes, libXp is used on our older build servers (for linux_xorg7 and linux_openmp) as a dependency of openmotif.
It does not seem to be needed for the more modern linux_fedora_21 package.
Maybe we should create a new build for Ubuntu 14.04 (which would hopefully work on 16.04, too).  That might resolve the problem, since those systems currently rely on linux_openmp.

column21:
Actually tested Fedora 21 and Ubuntu 14.04.  Fedora 21 does still depend on libXp.  Only Ubuntu systems (tested 14.04) do not seem to use it, apparently due to a different Motif package.  So at this point, only the 3 other_builds/ubuntu files seem to be candidates for a change, but I do not have an Ubuntu 12 system to verify even that much.
Are you actually building on Ubuntu 12, or is it 14 or 16?  If you are not testing on 12, then I would be more inclined to simply make new Ubuntu 14 files that do not include libXp (easier than creating a new system).

 LOADLIBES = $(LIBDIR) $(LIBS) $(IMAGELIBS)

 INSTALLDIR = $(HOME)/abin
 LIBDIR = $(INSTALLDIR)

column20:
Rational: AFNI relies on mpeg_encode for creating video clips. However, mpeg_encode is not maintained for years, has a problematic license/patent situation and is not available in any recent distribution. This patch replaces mpeg_encode with ffmpeg -- a more modern, maintained and available solution to achieve exactly the same result.
Originally written: 2009-10-29

The Makefiles are specific to our systems, and the ones that use those files do indeed need the -V option.
Expect to modify the Makefiles to suit your system peculiarities.  Consider starting with the Makefiles under other_builds instead, such as Makefile.linux_fedora_19_64 or Makefile.linux_ubuntu_12_64_OMP.  They even come with OS_notes files.

column13: WiP RF: the same .travis.yml to build/test both upstream and debian (if debian/ is present)
column20:
In neurodebian#5 decided to make .travis.yml test building of the debian package (instead of native upstream build which would fail since some 3rd party code gets dropped for debian pkg). So I thought that may be you guys wouldn't mind if those scripts live straight in your afni code base so we don't carry that patch, thus needing to deal with conflicts etc.
I will also test if it works when building against debian branch (ie instead of neurodebian#5) before removing the WiP

column20: Python uses half open ranges and matlab uses closed ranges. These produce identical results if there are not a round number of steps in the range , but when there are a round number of steps, Python will produce a range with one fewer value. This affected the time_series_time variable in PhaseEstimator.py, and this pull request addresses that case.
column21: Python uses half open ranges and matlab uses closed ranges. These produce identical results if there are not a round number of steps in the range , but when there are a round number of steps, Python will produce a range with one fewer value. This affected the time_series_time variable in PhaseEstimator.py, and this pull request addresses that case.

column20: Just a wild guess while waking up
column21:
I came across a relevant message (https://afni.nimh.nih.gov/afni/community/board/read.php?1,146837,146837):
a recently changed AFNI default is to auto-detach from terminal, which is probably more convenient for most users. There is just one small limitation if you use drive AFNI in a virtual X11 server environment (Xvfb) executed e.g. like this: 
xvfb-run -a --server-args='-screen 0 1280x1024x24' afni -com 'SAVE_JPEG A.axialimage sss.jpg' -com 'QUIT' 
> more details [afni.nimh.nih.gov] 

If you use a fresh AFNI version, you potentially get the following error: 
XIO: fatal IO error 11 (Resource temporarily unavailable) on X server ":100" 
after 16152 requests (16109 known processed) with 0 events remaining. 

My bug fix was rather simple and easy to share - just add the flag '-no_detach' to the afni drive command and all works as in previous versions. 
xvfb-run -a --server-args='-screen 0 1280x1024x24' afni -no_detach -com 'SAVE_JPEG A.axialimage sss.jpg' -com 'QUIT' 

will try and see if using the "no_detach" option when running the tests resolves the issue.

column20: Just a wild guess while waking up
column21: It seems that the no_detach option is afni specific, whereas the do.examples script contains many calls to DriveSuma (which /may/ cause the fatal IO error 11). So I'm not sure if the no_detach option can actually be used; or even whether it could fix the problem running the do.examples script on travis.

FIX: correct issue in AFNI Matlab library "unsplit_string" function
column20:
Minor fix in the AFNI Matlab library.
unsplit_string produces incorrect results if more than two strings are "unsplit". This results in incorrect NIML files being written.
ping @afni-rickr @afni-gangc

column13: FIX: correct issue in AFNI Matlab library "unsplit_string" function
column20:
Minor fix in the AFNI Matlab library.
unsplit_string produces incorrect results if more than two strings are "unsplit". This results in incorrect NIML files being written.
ping @afni-rickr @afni-gangc
column21:
Hi @afni-rickr, thanks for taking a look.
Remember that Matlab uses one-based indexing. With n elements, the for k loop makes k have values from 1 up to and including n -- not from 0 up to and including (n-1) as in the C language.
So if n==1, then the first loop iteration has also k==1, the guard if k<n evaluates to false, and no separator is added.
See also Matlab output:
>> unsplit_string({'foo'},'XX')

ans =

foo

>> unsplit_string({'foo','bar'},'XX')

ans =

fooXXbar

That said, I think your solution would work equally well :-)

column13: making error messages more helpful & clear
column20:
I ran into an issue today when AFNI tools were not able to write Nifti files to disk, and the supposed "NWAD ERROR" wasn't helpful to me identify the issue clearly.
** NWAD ERROR: wrote 0 of 491520 bytes of brick 1 of 96 to file++ 3dTshift: ...
...
** NWAD ERROR: wrote 8192 of 491520 bytes of brick 1 of 96 to file++ 3dTshift: ...

Although it could be deduced indirectly from "wrote only x of X bytes" message, this failure could be made more explicit to establish it as a "write failure" and nothing else.. Hence this PR.
Also I had to read the source code to figure out NWAD meant Nifti Write All Data, which is still a guess at this point :)

They already mention  errors when writing.  Also, without NWAD, a coder would have a lot more trouble locating the placement of the error in the code (there are very many places for write errors).  It is meant to make the error messages possibly unique in the code.

column21:
I made a more general commit that gets 'nifti' into the error messages that did not have it, and also added an 'only' for that exact case you mentioned (as in "wrote only...").  That seems more reasonable, so as to not put identical WRITE FAILURE text in so many places.
But you are editing nifti1_io.c, which is effectively no longer in use (by AFNI).  These changes are to nifti/nifti2/nifti2_io.c.  See c37fb14 .

column20: This would be extreme but it would drop the size of the repository by 200mb or so. It rewrites the history to no longer include the doc directory.
column21: This would be extreme but it would drop the size of the repository by 200mb or so. It rewrites the history to no longer include the doc directory.

column20:
This is to reduce the size of the repo. There various docs tutorials that I have removed. I followed the instructions here. So the command I ran for deletion was:
git filter-branch --force --index-filter 'git rm -r --cached --ignore-unmatch src/ptaylor/OLD_FAT_PRE_SCRIPTS src/SUMA/gts/doc/html doc/unix_tutorial doc/afni_sphinx doc/SphinxDocs' --prune-empty --tag-name-filter cat -- --all

This will require people to cherry pick any changes they've made on old branches to sync up (and then remove references to old branches and prune).
column21:

This will require people to cherry pick any changes they've made on old branches to sync up (and then remove references to old branches and prune).

this is planned to be used with niml output
from 3dinfo (not presently implemented)
It will also parse the niml element extracted
from the afni extension that is often saved in
a nifti header.
More extensive plans in this regard is to define
an xml schema for the niml element to allow
niml validation and automated parsing to the level
of typed arrays. This would also allow recursive
niml elements to be parsed with ease.

column21:
As a note, vastness is actually identical itall (at the moment at least).
It appears that the make build on circleci did not have the development version of python installed. #136 fixes this (and makes sure cmake and make have identical system installs from now on).
Additionally, it appears that the make build on circleci does not currently build SUMA. Since it is not the vastness/itall difference perhaps it is the clean etc that is done before the build that causes this deviation. I will investigate that further.
For now, the dev issue with the circleci (missing python header for building regex) is fixed.
Additionally, the original purpose of this pull request - tweaking the glut-header-includes to match system installed free glut on linux - has been resolved.

column20: A new communication method with the receiver has been added for the "All Data" configuration. In its original form the plugin would send 8 values per ROI voxel. With large ROI this can be a performance bottleneck. A new option "All Data (light)" has been added, that only sends one value per voxel. The old way of doing things remain under the label "All Data (heavy)"
column21: A new communication method with the receiver has been added for the "All Data" configuration. In its original form the plugin would send 8 values per ROI voxel. The old way of doing things remain under the label "All Data (heavy)"

column13: Updating code for Python 3 compatibility, and consistency with PyPI
column20: This update makes this set of code compatible with Python 3.  It also aligns the sources distributed with AFNI, to that used to build the 'afniRTI' packages distributed via PyPI.  It also includes a 'setup.py' - for users that would manually want to add this package to their existing Python or Conda installations.  It can also be used in a stand-alone fashion by the PsychoPy application on macOS and Windows.
column21: This update makes this set of code compatible with Python 3.  It also aligns the sources distributed with AFNI, to that used to build the 'afniRTI' packages distributed via PyPI.  It also includes a 'setup.py' - for users that would manually want to add this package to their existing Python or Conda installations.  It can also be used in a stand-alone fashion by the PsychoPy application on macOS and Windows.

column13: Fix typo in macro _AFNI_SETUP_HEADER_ used as header guard
column20:
Using the CMake build of AFNI on macOS 10.15 with AppleClang, there are 107 instances of header-guard warning:
../src/afni_setup.h:7:9: warning: '_AFNI_SETUP_HEADER_' is used as a header guard here, followed by #define of a different macro [-Wheader-guard]
#ifndef _AFNI_SETUP_HEADER_

Correcting the defined macro eliminates these warnings.

column20: Replace several usages of deprecated functions. The deprecated function drem is replaced by the C99 standard function remainderf, the deprecated function tmpnam is replaced by the POSIX standard function mktemp, and the deprecated function tempnam is replaced by the function mkstemps which is not standard by is available on Linux and macOS platforms at least. These replacements resolve several compiler warnings regarding deprecated declarations.
column21: Replace several usages of deprecated functions. The deprecated function drem is replaced by the C99 standard function remainderf, the deprecated function tmpnam is replaced by the POSIX standard function mktemp, and the deprecated function tempnam is replaced by the function mkstemps which is not standard by is available on Linux and macOS platforms at least. These replacements resolve several compiler warnings regarding deprecated declarations.

column21:
@afni-dglen, could you give this a try when on debian when you have a chance. This now checks explicitly for the suma error:
** ERROR: glwDrawingAreaWidgetClass is NULL
   This might be an error in GLwDrawA.h where the class is
   not referenced using 'extern'.  An alternative is to use
   the local build of libGLws.a.

I've encountered this repeatedly because homebrew and debian both ship the library in a form that breaks our build (the patch in the neurodebian repository has not yet been upstreamed). A quick fix is using -DUSE_SYSTEM_GLW=OFF, or resort to the GLw header modification hack by modifying the file installed on the system. Hopefully the longer term fix is that we upstream the change but for now at least an error from the undefined symbol occurs at build time rather than runtime.
Regarding the plugin error you encountered on OSX. Send on the error when you have a chance.  I can't reproduce it.

column20:
Resolves #130
Typical distribution will keep the executable files on the PATH (remaining in abin) but all importable python functionality will be moved into afni_python.  This will

allow namespacing:

from afni_python import afni_base
instead of:
import afni_base

enable an optional package install into a specific python interpreter (pip install -e afni_python). This helps to isolate the installation (for example installing the python code into a Conda environment) and enables external code to easily use afni's python functionality.
Will facilitate an easier install down the line for those of the python world who wish to simply use pip install afni_python and not have to do everything else... some thought will have to be put into support for tcsh functionality, some work is required to distribute pre-compiled c libraries/binaries via wheels or the like. This approach will likely exclude R dependencies and the GUI functionality of AFNI.

EDIT:  Ideally it would have been from afni import ... but the current distribution of afni (with executables in bin) prevent this because "afni" already exists in that directory. afnipy chosen to confirm with many XXXpy packages in the scientific python ecosystem

scripts in ptaylor would need some fixes for importing

column20:
Resolves #130
Typical distribution will keep the executable files on the PATH (remaining in abin) but all importable python functionality will be moved into afni_python.  This will

allow namespacing:

from afni_python import afni_base
instead of:
import afni_base

enable an optional package install into a specific python interpreter (pip install -e afni_python). This helps to isolate the installation (for example installing the python code into a Conda environment) and enables external code to easily use afni's python functionality.
Will facilitate an easier install down the line for those of the python world who wish to simply use pip install afni_python and not have to do everything else... some thought will have to be put into support for tcsh functionality, some work is required to distribute pre-compiled c libraries/binaries via wheels or the like. This approach will likely exclude R dependencies and the GUI functionality of AFNI.

EDIT:  Ideally it would have been from afni import ... but the current distribution of afni (with executables in bin) prevent this because "afni" already exists in that directory. afnipy chosen to confirm with many XXXpy packages in the scientific python ecosystem

column21:
Oh in that case this likely shouldn't merged. The principal reason for #154  is to allow more advanced users to install the python code into an environment for isolation/tying the installation to a python interpreter. It's true it serves as a stepping stone for a standalone pip installable package but there's a lot more to it than that. Having a pip installable package will only be especially useful when we have incorporated the C binaries into a pip wheel.
Agreed with Rick on the formatting changes. In general it would be nice to have the style more pythonic and conformant with pep8  etc. but fixing the large diff that it generates should typically done in a separate commit and is often not worth it due to the obfuscation of the git history.

column21:
It looks like this is really a URL change in setup.py, is that correct?

The second of these two commits, 8ccdbb8, is just a URL update in setup.py and a version bump; the first commit, a9831f4, is an update to several scripts (lib_afni1D, afni_base, afni_util, lib_timing, lib_vars_object & module_test_lib) from Python 2 syntax to Python 3.

was there a specific use case you had in mind?

We use lib_afni1D in some unit and regression testing for C-PAC (eg, https://github.com/FCP-INDI/C-PAC/blob/a6528ff9a2aea810fea6786a636dcf703ce2a943/dev/circleci_data/scripts/compare.py#L239) and are working to remove Python 2 dependencies from our package.
I didn't find a Python 3 version of lib_afni1d, so I

forked this repository
ran 2to3 on lib_afni1D and its internal dependencies
went through the automated changes and make adjustments
pip installed from my fork and tested my use case
updated the URL and build number in setup.py
opened a PR

The changes to spacing outside of actual updates to the Python syntax are automated changes from 2to3 and Atom. If it would be better for afni's flow, I can add a commit to revert the style changes and keep the substance.

Let me merge #154, then you can rebase, squash and merge this if you want. Until then  the import pattern would cause this to fail tests  if they had sufficient coverage (which unfortunately they do not). i.e. the current import afni_base can only be changed to from afni_python import afni_base on that other branch. And note, @afni-rickr  and I decided this should actually be from afni import afni_base. I'll ping you when #154 is merged.

column13: Small tweaks to the documentation for 3dMVM and 3dLMEr
column20:
Here are a couple of small suggestions for the documentation to 3dMVM and 3dLMEr. This was motivated because there seems to have been an accidental change to the -gltCode paragraph in 3dMVM in 2018 (commit 6f59613), so that much of that paragraph actually referred to F-tests and the end of the sentence was left dangling. I also combined items 2 and 4 from the NOTES section of -gltCode since they repeated one another and used the same example.
The trailing whitespace was trimmed automatically by my editor -- I have split those changes into separate commits to make it easier to see the substantive changes. I also fixed a few typos I noticed along the way, and a couple of broken web-links.

Apart from general improvements in the cmake build and its management of system dependencies this pull request also:

Fixes a bug in which CircleCI cache misses occur for the dev_base image (introduced by #180). It turns out that the default working_directory has a default value that changes across executors.
Uses xvfbwrapper, a python based tool for Xvfb used for tests
Alters the docker image entrypoints to improve compatibility with singularity
make some fixes to test data fetching that were not fully eradicated by #177 and #178

column20:
Resolves #194
A singularity behavior change causes the docker image to now break on some
clusters after conversion to singularity. This change may be reverted in future
versions of singularity. But who needs the time in a container?
apptainer/singularity#5465
EDIT: it's really just the work around that the change in singularity behavior fixes. Otherwise, the images are broken for usage with singularity on systems that bind in this way. Good to know... hopefully its fixed now

column21:
This is what it would look like with a code removal.
I think the following two git aliases might be helpful for such a thing:
git config --global alias.lc 'log --name-only  --pretty=format:"%n%n%nDeprecation: %s%nTimestamp: %ai%nCommit: %h%nAuthor: %an%nFiles affected:" HEAD~1..HEAD'
git config --global alias.deprecate '!git lc >> .deprecation.txt;git add .deprecation.txt; git commit -m "Code removal"'
After changes to build/licence/docs etc. one can add all of the C code changes in a single commit. Then running "git deprecate" will log all of the files changed, who dunnit, timestamp etc.
Subsequently if someone wished to restore the functionality, or just check how something was implemented they can do a quick search through .deprecation.txt

This pull requests tidies continuous integration for for the afni codebase
General improvements for test execution
Rather than resorting to bash scripts etc, testing functionality has
been consolidated into a python script run_afni_tests.py. The scripts
functionality itself is heavily tested so hopefuly moving forward this
will provide a robust interface to testing the full codebase.
The tests now run reliably on MacOS (with known failures Xfailed as
required)
Parallel test execution now works well. Race conditions for test data
download, Xvfb buffers, communication ports, Xquartz displays, and
environment variables have all been fixed so the more cpus the faster
the execution of the test suite. pytest-xdist was essential for this
(over pytest-parallel) because of the isolation it provides between
running tests. Additionally, lockfiles are used for the other race
conditions (process locks that worked with pytest-parallel will not work
here).
Timeout functionality is added for testing. This can be very useful some
times for commands that are known to hang across different executable
versions. It is also required for failures of suma, which when
backgrounded and listening on a port will never close...
Coverage testing
The coverage setup originally added by Ross Markello has been restored.
Previously, using coverage inflated the size of the development image to
18GB. A number of changes have been made this less of a problem. Among
others, the cmake build is now used, which uses shared libraries for all
libraries.
Additionally certain aspects of the build/CI infrastructure have altered

mrilib now has no X dependency
mcw_malloc memory stack monitoring is no longer used
the circleci setup is more modular and tag-specific jobs are being
used to reduce baseline resource usage.

Running coverage every push to github seems excessive but updating the
coverage for every release is now manageable.
Circleci/docker improvements
Circleci testing has been improved in a number of ways. The details of
data caching are now encapsulated in the python tool (permissions get
tricky as the user needs to be root on circleci but likely won't be
anywhere else). Additionally the executor used across the different jobs
has been homogenized.
Circleci executor changes were previously explored in #211. The solution
used here is to define an afni executor (docker image
afni/afni_circleci_executor) that contains all dependencies required on
circleci. The advantage of this is that now all circleci jobs can be run
locally using the circleci local CLI. The downside is that caching
test-data becomes more convoluted.
circleci mounts the host docker service into the executor as described here:
http://jpetazzo.github.io/2015/09/03/do-not-use-docker-in-docker-for-ci/
The circleci executor now has docker v19.03, which supports chown upon
copy. This chown on copy drops the size of the image. It also gives the
make_build access to /opt/afni/src (previously it was not worth the
increased image size to chown it)
run_afni_tests.py now manages test data during circleci testing. As
suggested by the circleci docs, it creates a container and mounts a
volume to it and then shares that volume with the main testing container
using the "volumes-from" option. Trickiness regarding
permissions/ownership are handled along with this.
Testing graphical user interfaces
The gui testing has proven extremely different to get working. The main
challenges were working with Xvfb (xvfbwrapper provides a more pleasant
interface from a pythonista point of view), race conditions for ports,
and the fact that suma does not raise non zero exit codes and hangs
indefinitely when a failure does occur. Additional challenge was working
out how to get opengl functionality working on MacOS using Xvfb (I
believe it is not possible unless Xquartz is recompiled with indirect
GLX support for Xvfb frame buffers). The solution was to run all suma
tests on the physical display of MacOS with the appropriate locking to
prevent race conditions.
Test data management
Test data for the testing suite is handled using datalad. This allows
convenient management of recursive git-annex repositories so large data
trees can be represented on disk without all of the data actually data
being there. Data management should not have afnipy as a hard
dependency. As tests are executed data that only exists as a symlink is
downloaded. Race conditions previously stymied robust behavior here but
it is now working really nicely. It has been encapsulated in the
data_management.py module for ease of reuse.

@mrneont this updates the circleci executors used. Updates on 2020/10/26 will remove some of the current circleci virtual machines (well actually 'descale', but its a slippery slope from there!). Additionally older versions of  remote docker will be removed.
For information on remote docker on circleci see this:
https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/building-docker-images/
A more recent version of remote docker is now explicitly defined to avoid any issues when the deprecation does occur.
Previously for the deployment step (pushing docker images to docker hub upon version updates) the virtual machine circleci/classic:201711-01 was used. This has been replaced here with the docker image docker:18.01.0-ce-git along with remote docker. This necessitates some fixes because the docker image is far more minimal (alpine OS is used). The upside of all of this is that the deployment step can now be executed easily on any machine that has docker and circleci installed with something along the lines of:
circleci local execute --job=deploy_cmake_build

I will say that this is not entirely complete though. I have not changed the executor for the tests step. And I want to explore the most efficient way to execute with respect to the test data. I can't directly mount previously cached test data into the container when using remote docker. Option
a) Do a more convoluted usage pattern for mounting the data
b) Forget about caching the data.
I'm leaning towards a). Less needless data downloading.

They should kick off but haven't for some reason. And it's not showing up. We can just wait or you can make some change and push that to wake it back up :) A useful tweak you could make to kill two birds with one stone  would be to rebase and force push. Something along the lines of:
git remote add afni https://github.com/afni/afni.git
git fetch afni
git rebase afni/master
# You need to force push as the history will have changed. 
# And you may have to replace roopchansinghv with origin
# This assumes you are using your master branch locally
git push roopchansinghv -f master:master

Or merge afni/master into your branch and push that. Whatever your preference is...

column20:
Turned stdout logging back on and updated data.
Found another bit of funniness with parallel execution for sample test data generation (though it does efffect the output directory in general). Output and sample directories now have a single directory per test session.
Verbosity levels have been changed to labels to be clearer and provide more
precise customization in future without confusing the current spectrum of
verbosity.

are rare).

reduce failures on CI. Enable with:
git config core.hooksPath .githooks

column13: tidy component management for cmake build
column20:
rename components to have a more homogenous naming scheme.
corelibs is now a component.
add functionality to install a restricted list of components. For
example, just install the gui targets... this is helpful for packaging
into components but is not flawless. For example all "external
dependencies" would have to use system dependencies or build them first
(or possibly use the cmake superbuild pattern to fully control the build
and installation prior to population of the afni projects targets)
docs, funstuff, and readme now installed along with gui as configurable
installation components.
python is now set as required for the build. 3.6 is now the oldest python
version supported by the python foundation. Using python for adding
functionality to the build management instead of cmake would like be easier.

docs, funstuff, and readme now installed along with gui as configurable
installation components.
python is now set as required for the build. 3.6 is now the oldest python
version supported by the python foundation. Using python for adding
functionality to the build management instead of cmake would like be easier.

column20:
Most substantial change is that test commands are now executed
asynchronously. This allows log output to be displayed in real
time and avoids an edge when sleeping process timeout instead
of returning an exit status.

column13: add fixes for local, test infrastructure path rewriting behavior, and extend cli of run_afni_tests.py
column20:
exposes functionality implemented in pytest's conftest.py in the run_afni_tests.py CLI.
Test output logs are modified at the time of comparison to pre-existing sample data from a previous run. This modification reduces spurious diffs occurring.
Command trimming is disabled for stdout/err. This was causing some issues with spurious diffs in the output logs for tests.
Rewriting of paths has been made more robust (previously it was not always rewriting the paths correctly and the functionality was untested)

column20:
@Shotgunosine, the build directory is now contained in source for coverage builds in the docker image.
I suspect this will work slightly better but I think full reporting of the coverage still won't work correctly. I think the codecov project directory needs to be set manually to /opt/afni/src. It currently uses the working directory during the tests /opt/afni/src/tests and then possibly /opt/afni/src/build directory. It may be that the codecov/coverage config files need to be moved up one level when the project dir is changed.
The pytest-cov plugin is used. It is configured as part of the pytest call with (this string)[https://github.com/afni/afni/blob/b7f60bb333e8c148ba8f1cda19a0cc5fc22d6d90/tests/afni_test_utils/minimal_funcs_for_run_tests_cli.py#L584]. My understanding is that this causes the coverage python to be used during the tests. The call to codecov subsequently uses the output from this  as well as collating the C coverage files (they are created because of build time flag), and finally uploading it.
The following gives an idea of required tweaks to get it working nicely previously:
git log -p 34ec36a79390ffda4d4f4dbeae3510c5bd3f8a60 tests

If you want to iterate locally the following should work with the circleci CLI (lack of circleci env variables will cause the upload to fail but otherwise everything should run identically to the cloud). The job has to build before the testing stuff happens so I suggesting using 50 cpus or so:
circleci local execute --job=coverage_check-0-5

column21: I think there are a few too many things blocking this from being merged. Closing for now

This is the start of reporting more about the ijk_to_xyz matrices in a dset--- what we refer to presently as aform_real, aform_orth and aform_card.
Presently, we are just using this information in 3dinfo--hence, only reporting on it, not doing anything with it yet.  Knowledge is half the battle!
Read the "Options for displaying ijk_to_xyz matrices" note about the matrices (in general, and specifically the aform_* ones) and the new opts for reporting on them.

column13: Basic MacOS 11.1, ARM CPU, Clang support
column20:
Minimal changes to support MacOS 11.1, ARM-based Apple Silicon CPUs, Clang compiler.

The file Makefile.macosx_11.1notes.txt provides instructions for compiling library dependencies from source.
All the tools compile, except SUMA.
All changes (with the exception of SUMA) use defined(__clang__) conditional. Therefore, these should not conflict with gcc builds.
Provisional SUMA changes use defined(__aarch64__) conditional. These should be reviewed once XQuartz supports this architecture.
It is possible to compile SUMA using the Makefile.macosx_11.01_alpha Makefile. However the resulting project does not work. I suspect the issue is that the libraries in /opt/X11/ are only compiled for x86-64, and the natively alternatives compiled by homebrew have a few different OpenGL functions ( glWindowPos2s(), glCheckFramebufferStatus()). Hopefully, once XQuartz is available natively it will be easy to compile SUMA. In the meantime, the translated SUMA works fine on M1 macOS.

column21:
Just going to add the notes I have been saving myself on XQuartz for Apple M1.  Hard to test since I don't have an M1 Mac yet and it looks like it'll be a while before we can purchase one.  Some transferred from (https://www.xquartz.org/releases/index.html).
Since Xquartz is not compatible with m1 Macs, one work around is to install xorg via macports:

Install MacPorts
sudo port install xorg
sudo port install xorg-server
X11.app will be installed in /Applications/MacPorts
Potentially profile to avoid exporting DISPLAY=:0
Logout and login

column13: Basic MacOS 11.1, ARM CPU, Clang support
column20:
Minimal changes to support MacOS 11.1, ARM-based Apple Silicon CPUs, Clang compiler.

The file Makefile.macosx_11.1notes.txt provides instructions for compiling library dependencies from source.
All the tools compile, except SUMA.
All changes (with the exception of SUMA) use defined(__clang__) conditional. Therefore, these should not conflict with gcc builds.
Provisional SUMA changes use defined(__aarch64__) conditional. These should be reviewed once XQuartz supports this architecture.
It is possible to compile SUMA using the Makefile.macosx_11.01_alpha Makefile. However the resulting project does not work. I suspect the issue is that the libraries in /opt/X11/ are only compiled for x86-64, and the natively alternatives compiled by homebrew have a few different OpenGL functions ( glWindowPos2s(), glCheckFramebufferStatus()). Hopefully, once XQuartz is available natively it will be easy to compile SUMA. In the meantime, the translated SUMA works fine on M1 macOS.
column21:
@pmolfese thanks for the tip. Curiously, homebrew can not build native X11 and macports can not natively build motif. However, using them together does appear to allow you to compile everything.

The macports X11 OpenGL headers lack two suma function calls. SUMA is built without these.


glCheckFramebufferStatus() for SUMA_display.c see Ziad's comments on 17 Dec 2013 about availability on some systems.
glWindowPos2s() for SUMA_volume_render.c this is only used once, with the default location: glWindowPos2s(0,0) so I am not sure it needed.


I am happy to send anyone with an ARM-based M1 my set of AFNI executables to test. I provide benchmarks for this architecture on Github. I do think this architecture has huge potential for our field, and it is a tribute to the AFNI developers that their work translates across architectures and compilers with so little effort. Presumably this is a reflection of how many architectures it has previously supported (MIPS, SPARC, PowerPC, x86-64). While everything compiles, one wants to make sure everything works correctly (e.g. impact of NaNs).

The file Makefile.macosx_11.1notes.txt provides instructions for compiling library dependencies from source.
All the tools compile, except SUMA.
All changes (with the exception of SUMA) use defined(__clang__) conditional. Therefore, these should not conflict with gcc builds.
Provisional SUMA changes use defined(__aarch64__) conditional. These should be reviewed once XQuartz supports this architecture.
It is possible to compile SUMA using the Makefile.macosx_11.01_alpha Makefile. However the resulting project does not work. I suspect the issue is that the libraries in /opt/X11/ are only compiled for x86-64, and the natively alternatives compiled by homebrew have a few different OpenGL functions ( glWindowPos2s(), glCheckFramebufferStatus()). Hopefully, once XQuartz is available natively it will be easy to compile SUMA. In the meantime, the translated SUMA works fine on M1 macOS.

column13: Basic MacOS 11.1, ARM CPU, Clang support
column20:
Minimal changes to support MacOS 11.1, ARM-based Apple Silicon CPUs, Clang compiler.

The file Makefile.macosx_11.1notes.txt provides instructions for compiling library dependencies from source.
All the tools compile, except SUMA.
All changes (with the exception of SUMA) use defined(__clang__) conditional. Therefore, these should not conflict with gcc builds.
Provisional SUMA changes use defined(__aarch64__) conditional. These should be reviewed once XQuartz supports this architecture.
It is possible to compile SUMA using the Makefile.macosx_11.01_alpha Makefile. However the resulting project does not work. I suspect the issue is that the libraries in /opt/X11/ are only compiled for x86-64, and the natively alternatives compiled by homebrew have a few different OpenGL functions ( glWindowPos2s(), glCheckFramebufferStatus()). Hopefully, once XQuartz is available natively it will be easy to compile SUMA. In the meantime, the translated SUMA works fine on M1 macOS.
column21:
@pmolfese thanks for the tip. Curiously, homebrew can not build native X11 and macports can not natively build motif. However, using them together does appear to allow you to compile everything.
1. The macports X11 OpenGL headers lack two suma function calls. SUMA is built without these.


* glCheckFramebufferStatus() for SUMA_display.c [see Ziad's comments on 17 Dec 2013](https://afni.nimh.nih.gov/pub/dist/doc/misc/history/afni_hist_BUG_FIX.html) about availability on some systems.

* glWindowPos2s() for SUMA_volume_render.c this is only used once, with the default location: `glWindowPos2s(0,0)` so I am not sure it needed.


1. I am happy to send anyone with an ARM-based M1 my set of AFNI executables to test. I provide benchmarks for this architecture [on Github](https://github.com/neurolabusc/AppleSiliconForNeuroimaging). I do think this architecture has huge potential for our field, and it is a tribute to the AFNI developers that their work translates across architectures and compilers with so little effort. Presumably this is a reflection of how many architectures it has previously supported ([MIPS, SPARC, PowerPC, x86-64](https://sscc.nimh.nih.gov/afni/doc/misc/afni_speed/)). While everything compiles, one wants to make sure everything works correctly (e.g. [impact of NaNs](https://developer.r-project.org/Blog/public/2020/11/02/will-r-work-on-apple-silicon/index.html)).



Hi @neurolabusc , thanks so much for translating AFNI software for M1 macs! Would you please send your set of executables to mengjia.lyu@pennmedicine.upenn.edu? Thank you for your efforts! Best, Mengjia

column13: Basic MacOS 11.1, ARM CPU, Clang support
column20:
Minimal changes to support MacOS 11.1, ARM-based Apple Silicon CPUs, Clang compiler.

The file Makefile.macosx_11.1notes.txt provides instructions for compiling library dependencies from source.
All the tools compile, except SUMA.
All changes (with the exception of SUMA) use defined(__clang__) conditional. Therefore, these should not conflict with gcc builds.
Provisional SUMA changes use defined(__aarch64__) conditional. These should be reviewed once XQuartz supports this architecture.
It is possible to compile SUMA using the Makefile.macosx_11.01_alpha Makefile. However the resulting project does not work. I suspect the issue is that the libraries in /opt/X11/ are only compiled for x86-64, and the natively alternatives compiled by homebrew have a few different OpenGL functions ( glWindowPos2s(), glCheckFramebufferStatus()). Hopefully, once XQuartz is available natively it will be easy to compile SUMA. In the meantime, the translated SUMA works fine on M1 macOS.

All the tools compile, except SUMA.
All changes (with the exception of SUMA) use defined(__clang__) conditional. Therefore, these should not conflict with gcc builds.
Provisional SUMA changes use defined(__aarch64__) conditional. These should be reviewed once XQuartz supports this architecture.
It is possible to compile SUMA using the Makefile.macosx_11.01_alpha Makefile. However the resulting project does not work. I suspect the issue is that the libraries in /opt/X11/ are only compiled for x86-64, and the natively alternatives compiled by homebrew have a few different OpenGL functions ( glWindowPos2s(), glCheckFramebufferStatus()). Hopefully, once XQuartz is available natively it will be easy to compile SUMA. In the meantime, the translated SUMA works fine on M1 macOS.
column21:
@DBermudez0 be aware that macOS places restrictions on ARM AArch64 executables that are not placed on x86-64 executables (even when the x86-64 executables are running on a M1 ARM architecture). Unless Daniel has provided app-specific passwords and notarized the executables, they may not work on your system. You may need to do tricks like codesign -s - exename and  xattr -dr com.apple.quarantine *.dylib to get these to run. Likewise, overwriting an executable seems to agitate M1 Macs, so an notarized executable will no longer work if it overwrites an existing executable, e.g. cp ./dcm2niix /usr/local/bin/dcm2niix will fail, requiring insteadrm /usr/local/bin/dcm2niix; cp ./dcm2niix /usr/local/bin/dcm2niix.
Given the numerous executables associated with AFNI, I would suggest your best approach is to build your own copy from source. As Daniel says, this allows you to keep up to date.

Minimal changes to support MacOS 11.1, ARM-based Apple Silicon CPUs, Clang compiler.

The file Makefile.macosx_11.1notes.txt provides instructions for compiling library dependencies from source.
All the tools compile, except SUMA.
All changes (with the exception of SUMA) use defined(__clang__) conditional. Therefore, these should not conflict with gcc builds.
Provisional SUMA changes use defined(__aarch64__) conditional. These should be reviewed once XQuartz supports this architecture.
It is possible to compile SUMA using the Makefile.macosx_11.01_alpha Makefile. However the resulting project does not work. I suspect the issue is that the libraries in /opt/X11/ are only compiled for x86-64, and the natively alternatives compiled by homebrew have a few different OpenGL functions ( glWindowPos2s(), glCheckFramebufferStatus()). Hopefully, once XQuartz is available natively it will be easy to compile SUMA. In the meantime, the translated SUMA works fine on M1 macOS.

column13: add mri_mini as a mechanism for encapsulating some of afni's functionality for a web assembly build.
column20:
@afni-rickr if you have some time over the next few days could you have a look at this. All the circleCI tests are passing so I think there should be no issue with the build used for distribution but perhaps you could confirm...
@afni-rwcox  is pondering a more substantial attempt at modularization/spring cleaning of the libmri headers but it may be that merging this as a separate set of changes beforehand makes that process more managable.

WIP:Add some tweaks to the cmake build for gentoo packaging
column20:
To begin, the cmake variables used to search for the python interpreter at configure time are user modifiable.
Another that detail that we need to solve is python code installation. Ideally this will use the portage distutils-r1 eclass mentioned by @TheChymera. If this works out then COMP_PYTHON should probably be set to off.
column21:
To begin, the cmake variables used to search for the python interpreter at configure time are user modifiable.
Another that detail that we need to solve is python code installation. Ideally this will use the portage distutils-r1 eclass mentioned by @TheChymera. If this works out then COMP_PYTHON should probably be set to off.

column13: WIP:Add some tweaks to the cmake build for gentoo packaging
column20:
To begin, the cmake variables used to search for the python interpreter at configure time are user modifiable.
Another that detail that we need to solve is python code installation. Ideally this will use the portage distutils-r1 eclass mentioned by @TheChymera. If this works out then COMP_PYTHON should probably be set to off.
column21:
It looks like providing the python source subdirectory, src/python_scripts, to the esetup.py function (see the portage eclass description for distutils-r1 should be sufficient. This should drive the appropriate installation of python source code. And to confirm, COMP_PYTHON should be set to OFF.
The current cmake build system either copies python files into the binary directory to mimic the current packaging approach (see
here). Alternatively, by default, it installs the afnipy package in development mode (source files are left in place and egg-info is add to the site packages of the "current" interpreter). This latter step is done here.
@afni-rickr,  I remember you were asking about this... adding -DSTANDARD_PYTHON_INSTALL=OFF should make the python code fully contained in the path you specify with DESTDIR.

column20:
This PR adds an integration operator to 3dMEPFM in order to estimate the innovation signal (i.e. the first derivative in time of the neuronal-related signal, which represents the neuronal-related signal as a piecewise constant as introduced in:

Uruñuela, E., Jones, S., Crawford, A., Shin, W., Oh, S., Lowe, M., & Caballero-Gaudes, C. (2020). Stability-Based Sparse Paradigm Free Mapping Algorithm for Deconvolution of Functional MRI Data. Proceedings of the Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society, EMBS, 2020-July, 1092–1095. https://doi.org/10.1109/EMBC44109.2020.9176137

column20:
Fixes to improve 3dECM:

updates sparse_array.c to abandon building similarity matrix as soon as memory budget is exceeded (previously would try to add a few more connections which would result in a string of out-of-memory errors)
fixed ridiculous seg fault that would occur when exiting on a error
changed it to only output binary ECM result when the -do_binary flag is specified, rather than every time
added descriptive label to the output buckets.

added descriptive label to the output buckets.

column20:
found a problem with 3dECM where the automatic threshold optimization when given a sparsity target would use a ton of memory. This is an issue when there are a bunch of time series for which the correlation is zero. Avoided this by eliminating all zero variance voxels prior to calculation.
updated 3dLFCD to be more in sync with the original publication by changing its default neighborhood to the six face touching voxels. The user can change this to faces+edges or face+edges+corners (the prior default) using command line arguments.
improved documentation for 3dECM and 3dLFCD

column13: Change CI test data to repo hosted on GIN
column20:
Changes the CI test data repository leej3/afni_ci_test_data hosted at gin.g-node.org. The repository on GIN does not require access to NIH or afni servers which makes it easier and more accessible to update test data. in the future.
Additionally, this repository is already updated with 3dClusterize data to fix the currently failing tests (Issue #266).

This tries to address the issues in publishing test data with datalad described in afni/afni_ci_test_data#2.
It also includes a breakage in tests that was fixed in #268 but it does not look like that is going to be merged.

column21:
Re: "Additionally suma is no longer compiling on MacOS... that error looks more extensive."  Does this refer to a CircleCi build error for Mac OS?
If that is the case, I think that is resolved---there was two issues that I could tell, each just involving a tweak of "#include .." statements:  in one case, for SUMA_input.c, an "#include .." pointed to a package that was just on a local machine (but we that dependency wasn't necessary, so could be fixed just by commenting that line); in another case, for 3dNwarpCalc.c, the recent addition of an if-condition required putting two simple "#include .."s in one branch of the condition.
@leej3 , could you please verify if these have resolved the issue(s) you were referring to?
Thanks.

column20:
Up until now, an INT_CMAP with N colors applies to an ROI dset with max value N, and sets its pbar max to also be N.
What should happen (and does happen now), is that an INT_CMAP with N colors applies to an ROI dset with max value N-1, and sets its pbar max to also be N-1.

column13: improve omp behavior in cmake build
column20:
addresses issues raised in #278
Now if USE_OMP is set by the user to OFF, an attempt at finding openmp is not done. In general
if OpenMP::OpenMP_C is not a defined target then afni targets do not link against omp or
define USE_OMP as a compile definition. Any deviation is a problem with the targets and should
be fixed. An example of a succesful implementation is:

  
    
      afni/src/CMakeLists_binaries.txt
    
    
        Lines 250 to 263
      in
      7bc3759
    
  
  
    

        
          
            add_afni_executable(${target} ${target}.c) 
        

        
          
            target_include_directories(${target} PRIVATE NIFTI::nifti2) 
        

        
          
            target_link_libraries(${target} 
        

        
          
            	PRIVATE 
        

        
          
            		AFNI::mri 
        

        
          
            		NIFTI::nifti2 
        

        
          
            		NIFTI::nifticdf 
        

        
          
            		$<TARGET_NAME_IF_EXISTS:OpenMP::OpenMP_C> 
        

        
          
            		m 
        

        
          
           ) 
        

        
          
           target_compile_definitions(${target} 
        

        
          
             PRIVATE 
        

        
          
             "$<IF:$<TARGET_EXISTS:OpenMP::OpenMP_C>,USE_OMP,>" 
        

        
          
            )

column13: Added support for IBM POWER8/9 architectures
column20:
Hello AFNI team!
We're running IBM POWER E880 servers in our HPC cluster infrastructure and I built AFNI for that architecture. Aside from putting together a corresponding Makefile, I had to tweak gts a little to make it work with gcc-8 (I updated config.guess and hacked ltmain.sh). Maybe these changes are useful for others who want to build AFNI on similar hardware.
All the best from Frankfurt,
Stefan

column21:
@jbteves you can also co-opt the code from the niimath compare function. In my experience, it is useful to have a tool that can help detect both identical as well as equivalent results. For example, an x86-64 computer will provide different results for a 32-bit float multiply-accumulate computation if you use the FPU (80-bit internal precision), SSE (64-bit), or a specialized AVX FMA instruction (64-bit, but one less rounding). Likewise, there are often differences when one uses a different architecture (NVidia Cuda, aarch64, x86-64). For this reason, I find it useful to report the most extreme difference between voxel pairs. Consider comparing two 4D images where the r is identical (1.0, at least to machine precision):
Images Differ: Correlation r = 1, identical voxels 73%
 Most different voxel -69.3133 vs -69.3133 (difference 1.52588e-05)
 Most different voxel location 43x17x49 volume 39
Image 1 Descriptives
 Range: -472.393..491.385 Mean -0.00121971 StDev 6.8898
Image 2 Descriptives
 Range: -472.393..491.385 Mean -0.00121971 StDev 6.8898

I do like how this not only reports the most discordant voxel, but its location on disk, allowing visual inspection.

column21:
Thanks for the tip @neurolabusc !
My intention here is to slowly expand the tool if people are interested. This is pretty much the "minimum viable product" for my use case, but there are significant other ways to expand the usefulness:

Add code to match the data types, or else upcast the less precise one and then compare (this is much more tricky, and for my immediate purposes just coercing to float32 actually works pretty well).
Add features to diff header elements. For example, if one file contains a header extension and another does not.
Print out what the differing dimensions are.
Intelligently determining whether the voxels diverge because they have different values, or if there is an implied mask (left has a 0.00--unlikely in floating-point for a real value, but right has a non-zero value; most likely this means that masks used to generate the images diverge, not necessarily that the underlying computations are different), and counting that up.
(As you mention) the minimum and maximum divergence in values; to be truly fancy, fill out a histogram.
Add Python bindings so that you can easily run diffs for testing frameworks such as pytest (any python implementation I've tried is just unbearably slow).
Add a -q flag to match the diff behavior of the same name: Just stop if there are any differences at all and return non-zero.
Add the ability to diff entire directories, which would let you do a little bit more seamless estimation of how much that "small change" impacted your data processing.

I'm sure there are other ways to improve things, too, but this is what I have off the top of my head. I do want to keep the program as light as possible; right now the runtimes are something like 250MB/s of diffing and I'm happy with that.

column21:
The THD_get_voxel() function (see thd_loaddblk.c) has the following syntax:
float THD_get_voxel( THD_3dim_dataset *dset , int ijk , int ival )
... where ijk is the index of element (e.g., voxel or surface node) and ival is the index of the volume (of a 3D or 4D set---in the former case, it would be 0).  This means this function can be applied to get values from 3D volumes or surfaces (or even *.1D files, if you transpose them after input).  So, your 3dDiff program could compare 3D volumes, surfaces, and more---even 4D files, if you looped over volumes (and you could output N values for two dsets of N subbricks).

column21:
Hi, @jbteves -
To your question about naming inputs:  indeed, switching from -left and -right makes sense to me.  Whether to go for, say:
A) "all files at end of command line"
B) explicit opts per file (-a/-b/... or -dset1/-dset2/...)
C) single argument that can take one or more files (e.g., "-infiles ..", like 3dmask_tool uses)
D) other
kind of depends on the future expanse of this program.
I might suggest B or C.  The appeal of "-a/-b/..." (or "-dset1/dset2/...) is brevity for 2 files, easy expandability for a few more, with possibilities for communicating text output about them by referring to each by their letter (or number).  Also, if the program expands, someday you might just add a "-infiles .." argument, to allow for lots of input datasets.  So, by the end of this paragraph, something from "B" for the moment, and possible expansion/change to "C" in the future.
Separate note:  the testing framework has finally been fixed (by the magical Yarik), and the shorter-term issue with CMake is also resolved in the current master branch.  So, I might suggest that you pull the master branch into this one---hopefully, there shouldn't really be any conflicts (maybe just minor Makefile stuff).
--pt

column21:
@jbteves :
I see.  From a scripting/programming point of view, having either all or the [0]th output be a clear "yes" or "no" seems appealing to me.  This could take the form:
1 25 16777216
... to show that yes, there is a difference (the leading 1) in 25 out of 16777216 voxels, and
0 0 16777216
... to show that no, there is no difference (leading 0) in 0 out of 16777216 voxels.  Note how the 2nd zero is still present, even if unnecessary, in order to keep the same number of outputs regardless of whether there is a difference.  Also, there is no text here (and even all a single type---integer), so it's easier to read in.  I think these features would help implementing this program in a script.  From this information, someone could readily calculate percentages, if needed, whether with a shell script:
#!/bin/tcsh

set vals = `3dDiff -a DSET1 -b DSET2`
if ( ${vals[1] ) then
    set perc = `echo "scale=10; ${vals[2]}/${vals[3]}" | bc`
    echo "++ The percentage diff is:  ${perc}"
else
    echo "++ There were no differences among the ${vals[3]} voxels."
endif

... or using the wacky Python that the kids these days are so crazy about.
And note that the above output applies generally whether the input is volumetric, grid, 1D, etc.
--pt

column21:
@jbteves
OK, I just ran the current code, and get no output for -a/-b dsets being the same, and this example for differencing:
$ 3dDiff -a mask.auto.nii.gz -b mask.auto_ALL1.nii.gz
++ Images diverge: 146997 of 211200 voxels disagree (69.601%)

So, sure, this is informative for a viewer.  I might change "voxels" to "elements, and "disagree" to "differ", and you might want to spit out the tolerance, too, even if unset:
++ Datasets differ: 146997 of 211200 elements (69.601%) differ at tolerance=[value]
Perhaps you might as well have friendly text for no difference:
++ Datasets do NOT differ: 0 of 211200 elements differ at tolerance=[value]
I would definitely add a "-programmy_output" option flag, for stark output noted above.  Or, have the brutalist output of only numbers be the default, and have a "-tell_me_nicely" (or "-descriptive") option to get more descriptive output.
re. Python bindings:  I am ignorant in how to do this, but I know it is possible, if programmed a certain (unknown-to-me-at-this-moment) way in C.

column21:
@jbteves -
OK, that looks good.  Are you sure you want to be in the business of evaluating header differences with this program?  I think I would take the approach of ensuring that the two input dsets are on the same grid (in the deep sense of 3dinfo -same_grid ...) and returning "fail" and nothing else if those headers don't match.  If they did match, then you could proceed with everything else.  This would shorten the output checklist, too.
Basically, I would think users should use 3dinfo to compare the header information (it's already good at that), and then this 3dDiff program would be about voxelwise/elementwise differences.  If the datasets have the same matrix dimensions but different placements in space (due to any part of the [q,s]form matrix), I wouldn't think a voxelwise/elementwise comparison would be possible/meaningful.  That kind of partitioning of comparisons (header for 3dinfo, data/brick for 3dDiff) seems useful to me.
--pt

column21:
Hm, that's an interesting thought. Right now what happens is it indicates that the differences are impossible/meaningless by returning a -1 for the voxel counts. The outputs have grown quite unwieldly already, and in theory this program could grow still (via things like adding a -mask option, a -scale option, etc.) So would your ideal version of this, given the tools in 3dinfo, look something like:

Run 3dinfo to check header differences
If there are header differences I detect, simply stop and tell the user "Hey, check out 3dinfo, you probably want to check with the following options..."
If there are no discernible difference, count them up and then just return a triplet of information or single message? (summary differs/doesn't differ, total differing elements, total elements compared)

Hm, I'd wondered about that myself since I feel like you could easily overflow that in my program. I'm also running into an issue trying to build my modified 3dinfo:
/bin/rm -f 3dinfo
/usr/bin/gcc -O2  -DDARWIN -m64 -Wcomment -Wformat -DUSE_TRACING -DHAVE_XDBE -DDONT_USE_MCW_MALLOC  -o 3dinfo 3dinfo.o -L. -L/usr/local/lib -L/opt/X11/lib -L/usr/lib -L/usr/lib -Wl,-x -Wl,-multiply_defined -Wl,warning -Wl,-bind_at_load  -lmri -lf2c -lXm -ljpeg.9 -lXt -lXft -lfontconfig -lpng16 -liconv -lXmu -lXp -lXpm -lXext -lX11 -lz -lexpat  -lm -lc
Undefined symbols for architecture x86_64:
  "_THD_count_diffs", referenced from:
      _main in 3dinfo.o
  "_space_to_NIFTI_code", referenced from:
      _main in 3dinfo.o
ld: symbol(s) not found for architecture x86_64
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
make: *** [3dinfo] Error 1

While I realize this must mean I'm not correctly getting my new THD_count_diffs function included in libmri, I'm reasonably sure I haven't mangled space_to_NIFTI_code. Any thoughts on what the issue could be? I'm realizing now also that 3dDiff shouldn't need to include the thd_mismatch object file since that should be in the library, so this is probably a local setup issue but I'm not sure.

column21:
Hi-
Slightly late to this party, which has been going strong this morning!
I think it would be better to just focus on 3dDiff, rather than mirror this functionality in 3dinfo, too.  At present, it seems possible to have have a simple option in 3dinfo, but I imagine the desired functionality of 3dDiff will quickly grow---as soon as you mention adding a mask (which seems a natural addition), then this no longer is in the realm of 3dinfo.  Then, you are stuck with awkwardly duplicating, or branching, or something else that can be avoided.  I am quite surprised that 3dinfo has -val_diff, actually... though I aaaaalways learn surprising things about the code base.
Many programs in AFNI work volume by volume---I suspect this would be a handy model here.  Rather than going for Nvox * Nval, when contemplating multivolume data, why not just treat each 3D volume separately?  The output could have N rows, then, one for each:
0   0  100000
0   0  100000
1 20  100000

You could also have a separate option for just one, summary row, either keeping the same format or adding a 4th column (number of volumes):
$ 3dDiff -a dset1.nii.gz -b dset2.nii.gz -diff_across_time
1   20  100000 3

... where now the 4th column is the number of volumes (in lieu of 3 columns, with the final value being 300000).  Even if there is only 1 volume, it could be there.  It isn't so wonderful changing the format output, perhaps (3 columns of numbers to 4), but at least if the user adds that option explicitly, then they can know what to expect.
It also seems more meaningful to me to leave the Nvox and Nvalue info separately reported---can be useful to know, and most Nvox and Nvals are not so easily to decouple.
--pt

column21:
I'm actually quite confused by it as well, it struck me as an odd thing to include, yet when I was going hunting for header checking flags, it was right there alongside -same_grid. I like the idea of offering a tabular representation of the diffs, and an optional way to one-line it. This seems like a satisfactory way to avoid printf macros, which is deeply, deeply preferable from a newbie developer point of view... Additionally, you could make a more complete summary, such as:
Found differences in X of N volumes (P%), with total differing voxels ranging from A elements (a%) to B elements (b%)

So I'll work on making those changes.
Another potentially dumb question: why not add the LIBMRI_OBJ dependency to those files? It's already present in many of the makefile lines and proofs it a bit against future me. I don't trust that guy, he has a checkered past with following instructions, even from (and perhaps especially from) himself.
@pmolfese other than liking having multiple ways to do things, do you have a compelling argument for me to keep that change in 3dinfo? It did seem quite out of place, and the behavior is a little bit weird because you actually get the same number back twice since it's designed to potentially compare many files.

column21:
I will haaapppily defer libmri questions to @afni-rickr .
3dinfo is generally best for getting info about a single dataset, and often for header-related items.  There are some data-related ones (e.g., min and max values), but that is rare.  There are a couple cases for comparing multiple files---namely, in that section you have pointed to, with the semi-commonly-used -same_grid, which performs the role of THD_dataset_mismatch() in shell scripts.  But for the most part, data-querying functionality tends to reside elsewhere happily, because it often gets more complicated such as by adding a mask.  Perhaps even the -*val_diff options exist in 3dinfo because a timetraveling or alterate-reality-hopping JBT put it there, before realizing that programming a new C progarm would be even more fun than editing an existin gone.
--pt

So given that, would you prefer that the one-line option retain the number of volumes and voxels as separate items, or to use a double and then truncate the decimal and print out the total number of elements compared, and then print it out as one item? (Though I suppose even this could be made into an option).

column21:
So, the issue is that intead of having a small number of total diffs:
$ 3dDiff -a dset1.nii.gz -b dset2.nii.gz -diff_across_time
1   20  100000 1000

... it could try to look like:
$ 3dDiff -a dset1.nii.gz -b dset2.nii.gz -diff_across_time
1   5000000000  100000 50000

... and unfortunately the number of diffs is greater than 2**31, so this will create an overflow problem?
That is a very large number of diffs (a high-res, 50k volume dataset) that would lead to that.  But you could guard against it in a few ways:

putting a ceiling value on the number of diffs (2**31, say)
outputting the number of diffs as 5.0e+9 (that is, jumping to %e for printing output)
outputting a -1 as the second number, to signify that the number of differences are "a lot", in a technical sense:
1   -1  100000 50000

--pt

Just google "Josh's living nightmares," should pop right up.
To make a suggestion:

Go to files changed
Click on the plus sign next to the line you want to make a suggestion on (or use Shift and click on multiple lines, which turn yellow, and then click the plus sign)
Click "Make a suggestion," which will plop the current version in a block surrounded by backticks
Replace it with your suggestion

column20:
3dEulerDist:  a program for calculating the Euler Distance Transform (EDT) in C code.
This code calculates the Euclidean Distance Transform (EDT) for 3D
volumes following this nice, efficient algorithm, by Felzenszwalb
and Huttenlocher (2012;  FH2012):
Felzenszwalb PF, Huttenlocher DP (2012). Distance Transforms of
Sampled Functions. Theory of Computing 8:415-428.
https://cs.brown.edu/people/pfelzens/papers/dt-final.pdf
Another useful/illustrative resource about this is by Philip Rideout:
https://prideout.net/blog/distance_fields/
The current code here extends/tweaks the FH2012 algorithm to a more
general case of having several different ROIs present, for running
in 3D (trivial extension), and for having voxels of non-unity and
non-isotropic lengths.  It does this by utilizing the fact that at
its very heart, the FH2012 algorithm works line by line and can even
be thought of as working boundary-by-boundary.
Here, the zero-valued "background" is also just treated like an ROI,
with one difference.  At a FOV boundary, the zero-valued
ROI/backgroud is treated as open, so that the EDT value at each
"zero" voxel is always to one of the shapes within the FOV.  For
nonzero ROIs, one can treat the FOV boundary either as an ROI edge
(EDT value there will be 1 edge length) or as being open.
This code follows the earlier lib_EDT.py library version written by PA Taylor and earlier distanceField program by P Lauren.

column20:
This program calculates edges in an image using the Difference of Gaussians
(DOG) method by Wilson and Giese (1977) and later combined with work by
Marr and Hildreth (1980) to provide a computationally efficient
approximation to their Lagrangian of Gaussian (LOG) method for calculating
edges in an image.  This is a fascinating set of papers to read.  But you
don't have to take my word for it!...
Generating edges in this way has some interesting properties, such as
numerical efficiency and edges that are closed loops/surfaces.  The edges
can be tuned to focus on structures of a particular size, too, which can be
particularly useful in some applications.
The primary papers for learning more about the DOG and LOG methods are:
Wilson HR, Giese SC  (1977). Threshold visibility of frequency
gradient patterns. Vision Res. 17(10):1177-90.
doi: 10.1016/0042-6989(77)90152-3. PMID: 595381.
Marr D, Hildreth E (1980). Theory of edge detection. Proc R Soc
Lond B Biol Sci. 207(1167):187-217.
doi: 10.1098/rspb.1980.0020. PMID: 6102765.
Thanks to C. Rorden for pointing these paper out and discussing them.
The current code here extends/tweaks the MH1980 algorithm a bit.  It runs
in 3D by default (a straightforward extension), it also employs the
Eulerian Distance Transform (EDT) to pick out the actual edges from the
DOG step---see 3dEulerDist for more information about the EDT.

column13: DRG's updates to scripts for starting post-InfantSurfer analyses
ENH - updated code to be able to read out the atlas label table
column20: Context: the Fieldtrip matlab toolbox allows for reading in atlases from various formats. Currently, there is hard coded support for the TT+tlrc atlas in (https://github.com/fieldtrip/fieldtrip/blob/master/fileio/ft_read_atlas.m) but I'd rather have this a bit more generic. It seems possible to decode from the files' *.HEAD the necessary information, without the need to rely on a hard coded list of labels/values. Of course I can easily solve this on our end, but perhaps it's more futureproof to solve it at the level of reading in the data into MATLAB. This PR attemps to resolve this.

Hi, @schoffelen : Thanks for contributing this to the repo.  We don't really do a lot with the Matlab codes here (as you might have noticed...), but it is good to know they are still useful.
Would you have an example or two of the commands for which you are adding functionality, just for our own information (and perhaps which could be added in a help)?
Thanks.

column21:
Dear Paul @mrneont, I indeed noticed that the matlab-code does not seem to heavily used / actively developed :). Initially I PR'ed into Zaid's afni_matlab repo, but I thought it would be potentially more useful to PR closest to the source.
My point indeed is that I can come up with a local workaround, i.e. interpret the *.HEAD header information on our end (i.e. adding some stuff to our local version of the file readers) but perhaps it's better on the long run to synchronize on both ends.
Sure I can provide some test code or demo the functionality. Also, no problem for me to update the functions' documentation a bit. Will do.
